Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: I was standing in the checkout line, my mind half on the Torah class I was scheduled to teach in less than an hour, when I saw my son slip a candy bar into his pocket. My heart dropped. As a parent, I knew I had to address this immediately—teach him right from wrong, help him understand the seriousness of stealing, and guide him toward making amends. But as a rabbi, I also felt the weight of my commitment to the community. The adult education class was optional, but people counted on me to be there, to share wisdom and foster discussion. I could already imagine the disappointment if I canceled last minute. My son’s wide, guilty eyes met mine, and I felt the pull in both directions—my duty to him as his parent, and my responsibility to my congregation as their rabbi. My mind raced, torn between the urgent need to teach my child a lesson in honesty and the expectation that I would be present for my students, ready to teach Torah.
